Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Child Tracking and Detection - A Public Safety Application Through Mobile Crowd-Sensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Based on principles of Mobile Crowd-Sensing, this project implements a Public Safety application for tracking children.

Child protection is a critical global public safety issue. Keeping track of young children is often a daunting task for parents. The responsibility is especially challenging for parents with special-needs children. One social effort to track missing children, the AMBER Alert Program, focuses on galvanizing an entire community to assist in the search for and safe recovery of missing children. While the AMBER Alert Program's coverage of social monitoring has significantly broadened in recent years, including phone messaging and online social media, successful recoveries are often far too slow, the success rate is very low, and the process is costly. This team's technology automates aspects of AMBER Alert and radically improves the effectiveness through innovative wireless and cloud technologies.

This project effectively and efficiently utilizes crowds to protect children using technology that provides a faster, better, and less expensive solution. The project involves WiFi tags for children and smartphone apps for parents, caregivers and volunteers. This team prototyped the technology with all of the components of a child tag prototype plus the smartphone app with parent mode, caregiver mode, and a volunteer mode. In addition to the main focus, child protection, the team will explore other markets of the proposed innovation such as pet owners, amusement parks, malls, educational institutions, retail, and hospitals. In addition to direct manufacturing and distribution, the team is open to licensing the proposed technology to other location tracking device makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wandering, also called elopement, is when someone leaves a safe area or a responsible caregiver, and is an important safety issue that affects some people with disabilities, their families, and the community.  Wandering may lead to situations where the person may be injured or harmed or lost. Some people -- especially children and youth -- with special needs, such as those with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) or intellectual disability (ID), have difficulties in understanding safety issues and communicating with others.  For example, those individuals might run away from a safe place to somewhere they wouldn't recognize. They are often drawn to water such as a pond or a lake which can cause them being drowned. Drowning is indeed a leading cause of premature deaths of people with special needs. Even when someone finds the person lost, she might be unable to respond to her name or say where she lives making them even difficult to be taken back to her home. Even under constant human supervision, this can happen quickly, leaving only the option of desperate manual searching, perhaps with the help of first-responders or a community through a social alert system like Amber alert. In addition, the families and caregivers of people with special needs who are at risk of wandering or eloping behavior have to keep them in their sight all the time, leaving little time to care for themselves. This situation leads the families and caregivers themselves to often restrain or shut out from their own social lives. Despite there are many commercial products to help to find missing people, most of them are expensive, do not work well, or are not effective as it can be.

Their loved one’s being unaccounted for is an excruciating experience, even if it is for a short moment. Our product will give a peace of mind to caregivers in normal times. Finding any missing person will have an enormous societal impact, in addition to being far more effective, efficient, and expeditious while also being less cost prohibitive.

The intellectual merit of this project includes innovative use of WiFi beacon technology for opportunistic crowd sensing, data and communication security, sensing effectiveness, and user resource utilization of smart devices.  While the concept of crowdsensing, the sensing paradigm of using mobile devices carried by humans for a collaborative objective is not new, it has not yet been widely deployed. This project directly addresses several core social and technical challenges to realize them it into practice. The core set of methods and processes of the project that can be replicated, adapted, and used in other crowd sensing applications in smart and connected communities.

We have conducted more than 130 customer discovery interviews to learn about customer segments that have dire needs of the technology with commercial viability. From the initial broad set of customer segments, we have narrowed down the initial customer segment that is caregivers of people with special needs.  We have also developed preliminary prototypes of the software and hardware components. In addition, we have actively showcased the technology and its potential at a number of institutions and meetings through technical talks.
